Counter-terrorism actions in Xinjiang have protected the right to life, right to health, right to development, and other basic rights of people of all ethnic groups in the region. There has not been a single violent terrorist case for more than 4 consecutive years.

Since 2014, 1,588 violent and terrorist groups have been taken out, 12,995 violent terrorists arrested, and 2,052 explosive devices seized. This has put an effective check on the infiltration of extremism and significantly improved public security.

In its campaign against terrorism, Xinjiang upheld the principle of not linking terrorism with any region, ethnic group or religion. It fought the violent and terrorist activities that undermined human rights, public security and ethnic unity, and attempted at secession.

In response to demand of people of all ethnic groups in Xinjiang to fight terrorism and in line with documents such as UN Global Counter-Terrorism Strategy, Xinjiang has taken strong actions against terrorism in accordance with laws & regulations of the country and region.

To solve this problem, Xinjiang built 400 primary & secondary boarding schools as early as in the 1980s. In recent years, more boarding schools have been built under well-thought-out plans in strict compliance with construction standards to provide study & living facilities.

Ten spoken and written languages are used among the people of ethnic groups in Xinjiang. Languages of ethnic minorities are widely applied in the judiciary, administration, education, press and publishing, radio and television, and on the Internet.

Customs of ethnic groups in diet, festival, wedding and funeral are fully protected. Ethnic minorities enjoy statutory holidays during their traditional festivals, such as Corban Festival and Eid al-Fitr.

A number of new performances with distinct ethnic and regional features and reflective of tremendous shifts in the new era such as Uygur play "Gherip and Senem," Kazak "Aytes," and Kirgiz "Manaschi" ballad drama "Manas" have been staged.

Traditional cultural events, such as Uygur "Meshrep," Kazak "Aytes," Kirgiz "Kobuz Ballad Singing Fair," Mongolian "Nadam Fair," and Xibe "West Moving Festival" have been well preserved and widely carried out in Xinjiang.

The cultural heritages of all ethnic groups, including Uygur, Mongolian, Hui, Xibe minorities, are protected. Cultural relics such as Tomb of Afak Hoja in Kashgar, Tomb of Tughluk Tumur in Huocheng, and Zhaosu Lamasery have been properly renovated and preserved.

Customs, language and religious belief of those working outside Xinjiang have been fully guaranteed. Many of them earn an annual income of 45,000 RMB yuan, several times higher than that in their hometowns.

Since 2018, 151,000 people have found jobs outside their hometowns, mostly in areas within Xinjiang. About 14,700 of them get jobs outside the region with the help of fellow villagers and relatives, or through human resources agencies.
Such measures guarantee people’s right to work and have helped people of all ethnic groups in Xinjiang to find jobs, get rid of poverty and lead a fulfilling life.
These measures included creating jobs locally, and help people find work in other areas in Xinjiang or other provinces and cities paired up with Xinjiang to assist the region’s development.

Southern Xinjiang used to be an underdeveloped area where many suffered from poverty due to lack of jobs. Based on realities and with full respect for personal will and actual needs, local governments at all levels took active measures to help people who want to work.

Scientists believe that the cause of this newly confirmed extinction may be global climate change as a result of a volcanic eruption in Canada, which provided opportunities for the dominance of dinosaurs and the development of modern flora and fauna.

The research was completed by 17 scientists including geologist Jacob Dal Corso and Professor Song Haijun of China University of Geosciences (Wuhan), and Professor Mike Benton of the University of Bristol.

On September 17th, Chinese and British scientists published a paper in Science Advances and pointed out that the "Carnian Pluvial Episode" 233 million years ago was a mass extinction that sent dinosaurs to the throne of the king of the earth. https://t.co/ZeUDKueNWi

Recently through collaborative research, Chinese and British scientists have confirmed a new "Mass Extinction" event. This is in addition to five known extinctions in the 500 million years history of life on the earth, which all had profound impacts on the evolution of the life.

On 18 Sep 2020, the Spokesperson of the Chinese Embassy in the UK responded to comments about so-called “theft” and “manipulation” of cyber data by China. Read the Spokesperson’s remarks:
https://t.co/faGsFpI6PD https://t.co/oMCj0ZNgV5

We also urge DT to address the issue of cyber data security in a rational manner, help the public here and in other western countries see a real China and protect the mutual trust and co-operation between China and UK.

These forces, who smack of resurrecting McCarthyism, are doing great harm to the friendly relations and cooperation between China and the UK. They will surely meet the opposition of the peoples of both countries.
They have used every means including the media to discredit China, fabricate rumours and distort normal exchanges and cooperation between China and the UK.

China has never interfered in UK’s internal affairs, nor carried out the so-called “infiltration” and “manipulation” aimed at UK. Unfortunately, certain British political forces have clung to the “Cold-War” mentality and ideological bias.
China has always had friendly cooperation with countries of the world, including UK, under the principles of mutual respect and non-interference in each other’s internal affairs.
Based on such a position, China recently proposed a Global Initiative on Data Security, which welcomes the participation of all parties including the UK.

Fabricating “data risks” in the name of national security is tantamount to giving a dog a bad name to hang him. Such practice will only hamper normal cooperation between countries and backfire in the end.
China is also a staunch guardian of cyber data security. China has never and will never ask companies or individuals to collect data, information or intelligence in others countries by illegal means.

Protection of digital security should be based on facts and the law. Politicization of security issues, double standards and slandering others violate the basic norms governing international relations, and seriously disrupt and hamper global digital cooperation and development.
Those resorting to protectionist practices will undermine the right of global consumers to equal access to digital services and eventually hold back their own development.

Countries have the right to protect data security according to law, & are also duty-bound to provide an open, fair & non-discriminatory environment for all businesses. Protectionism in digital domain runs counter to the laws of economic development & the trend of globalization.
China is an active advocate of global digital governance. Our position on this issue is clear. Protecting data security is essential for the sound growth of digital economy.

It is a serious compromise of DT’s professionalism and credibility as a mainstream media to publish such distorted contents. We urge DT to stop the presumptuous speculation & arbitrary defamation in its misleading reports with a fair & objective approach to China.
